messageBody:
I already looked at it a few days ago. I think the Theories are indeed a
step in the right direction. However, it is only a part of it. By using
theories, I can test that a class implements correctly its own contract.
However, I cant test if a class respects the contract of its collaborators.
What I miss is the ability to mock my collaborators in order to check its
contract.



Thanks for the link anyway,



Gilles

com> wrote:
> Finally, my last "dream" is probably much less clear than the two
> previous points, and certainly more complex.
> I would like to see TDD colaborates with design by contract to give an
> intermediate aproach taking the best of the two world.
> I would like to be able to define somehow the contract of an
> interface, and I would like to have this contract validated when I run
> the test, and that even when I stub or mock the object. I'm convinced
> that would allow to write more powerful tests that would be less brillant.
> And ho, I forgot! My dream is to see that in java. :-)

Gilles,

Have you checked out Popper? http://popper. <http://popper.tigris.org>
tigris.org

If that's not a step in the direction you're talking about, I'd
welcome your feedback, here or in person. Thanks,

David Saff
